title: Active users
text:
Active users is a measurement metric that is commonly used to measure the level of engagement for a particular product or object, by quantifying the number of active interactions from visitors within a relevant range of time (daily, weekly and monthly). The metric has many uses in both <a href="commerce">commerce</a> and academia, such as on <a href="social%20networking%20service">social networking services</a>, <a href="online%20game">online games</a>, or <a href="mobile%20app">mobile apps</a>. Although having extensive uses in digital behavioural learning, prediction and reporting, it also has impacts on the privacy and <a href="Data%20security">security</a>, and ethical factors should be considered thoroughly. Like any metric, active users may have limitations and criticisms. Active Users is relatively new or <a href="Neologism">neologistic</a> in nature, that became important with the rise of the commercialised internet, with uses in communication and <a href="Social%20networking%20service">social-networking</a>. It measures how many users visit or interact with the product or service over a given interval or period. This metric is commonly assessed per month as monthly active users (MAU), per week as weekly active users (WAU), per day as daily active users (DAU) or peak concurrent users (PCU).
Commercial usage.
Predictors of success engagement measurement (KPI) and advertisement.
Active users on any time scale offers a rough overview of the amount of returning customers a product maintains, and comparing the changes in this number can be used to predict growth or decline in consumer numbers. In a commercial context, the success of a <a href="Social%20networking%20service">social-networking-site</a> is generally associated with a growing network of active users (greater volume of site visits), social relationships amongst those users and <a href="User-generated%20content">generated contents</a>. Active Users is can be used as a <a href="performance%20indicator">performance indicator</a>, <a href="Performance%20measurement">managing</a> and <a href="Prediction">predicting</a> future success, in measuring the growth and current volume of users visiting and consuming the site. The ratio of DAU and MAU offers a rudimentary method to estimate <a href="customer%20engagement">customer engagement</a> and retention rate over time. A higher ratio represents a larger retention probability, which often indicates success of a product. Ratios of 0.15 and above are believed to be a tipping point for growth while sustained ratios of 0.2 and above mark lasting success. Chen, Lu, Chau, and Gupta (2014) argues that greater numbers of users (<a href="Early%20adopter">early adopters</a>) will lead to greater <a href="user-generated%20content">user-generated content</a>, such as posts of photos and videos, that "promotes and propagates" social media acceptance, contributing to social-networking-site growth. The growth of social media use, characterised as increase of active users in a pre-determined timeframe, may increase an individual's <a href="Social%20presence%20theory">social presence</a>. <a href="Social%20presence%20theory">Social presence</a> can be defined as the degree to which a social-networking communications medium allows an individual to feel present with others, Moon and Kim's (2001) research results found that individual's <a href="Pleasure">enjoyment</a> of web systems have positive impacts on their <a href="Perception">perceptions</a> on the system, and thus would form "high behaviour intention to use it". Munnukka (2007) have found strong <a href="Correlation%20and%20dependence">correlations</a> between positive previous experience of related types of <a href="Communication">communications</a> and <a href="adoption">adoption</a> of new mobile <a href="Social%20networking%20service">site communication services</a>. However, there are also cases where active users and revenue seemed to have a negative <a href="Correlation%20and%20dependence">correlation</a>. For instance, Snap Inc.'s gains in daily active users (DAU) have <a href="Stable%20%E2%88%9E-category">stabilised</a> or decreased during the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 Pandemic</a>, revenue still exceeded estimates, with strong similar strong trends in the current period.
Greater number active users boost the number of visits on particular sites. With more traffic, more <a href="Advertising%20agency">advertisers</a> will be attracted, contributing to <a href="Media%20Revenue%20Generation">revenue generation</a>. In 2014, 88% of <a href="corporation">corporation</a>'s purpose of social media usage is <a href="advertising">advertising</a>. Active Users increase allows <a href="Social%20networking%20service">social-networking sites</a> to build and follow more customer profiles, that is based on customer's needs and consumption patterns. Active user data can be used to determine high traffic periods and create behavior models of users to be used for targeted advertising. The increase of customer profiles, due to increase of active users, ensures a more relevant <a href="Personalization">personalised and customised</a> advertisements. Bleier and Eisenbeiss (2015) found that more <a href="Personalization">personalised</a> and <a href="Relevance">relevant</a> advertisements increase "<a href="View-through%20rate">view-through</a> responses" and strengthen the <a href="effectiveness">effectiveness</a> of "the advertised <a href="Web%20banner">banner</a>" significantly. DeZoysa (2002) found that consumers are more likely to open and responsive on personalised advertisements that are relevant to them.
External reporting purposes.
The <a href="Financial%20Accounting%20Standards%20Board">Financial Accounting Standard Board</a> defines that objective of financial reporting is provide relevant and material financial information to financial statement users to allow for decision making and ensure an efficient economic |resource allocation. All reporting entities, primarily <a href="Public%20company">publicly listed companies</a> and large <a href="Privately%20held%20company">private companies</a> are required by law to adhere to disclosure and accounting standards requirements. For example, in Australia, companies are required to comply with <a href="Accounting%20standard">accounting standards</a> set by the <a href="Australian%20Accounting%20Standards%20Board">Australian Accounting Standards Board</a>, which is part of the <a href="Corporations%20Act%202001">Corporations Act 2001</a>. In social media company's context, there is also reporting of non-financial information, such as the number of users (active users). Examples may include:
Source: Weitz, Henry, Rosenthal (2014)
Alternative methods of reporting these <a href="Metric%20system">metrics</a> are through social networks and the web, which have become important part of firm's "information environment" to report financial and non-financial information, according to Frankel (2004), whereby firm relevant information is being spread and disseminated in short spans of time between networks of investors, journalists, and other intermediaries and stakeholders. Investment blogs aggregator, like <a href="Seeking%20Alpha">Seeking Alpha</a>, has become significant for professional <a href="Financial%20analyst">financial analysts</a>, who give <a href="Recommender%20system">recommendations</a> on buying and selling stocks, and influence <a href="Volume%20%28finance%29">stock volume</a> and <a href="Price">prices</a>. Studies by Frieder and Zittrain (2007) have raised new concerns about how digital <a href="Information%20and%20communications%20technology">communications technologies</a> <a href="Operational%20reporting">information reporting</a> have the ability to affect <a href="Market%20participant">market participants</a>.
Admiraal (2009) emphasised that nonfinancial metrics reported by <a href="social%20media">social media</a> companies, including active users, may give not desirable assurance in success measurements, as the guidance, and reporting <a href="Regulation">regulations</a> that safeguards the <a href="Reliability%20%28statistics%29">reliability</a> and <a href="Data%20quality">quality</a> of the information are too few and have not yet been <a href="Standardization">standardized</a>. Cohen et al. (2012) research on a set of economic performance indicators found that there is a lack of extensive <a href="Convention%20of%20disclosure">disclosures</a> and a material <a href="Statistical%20dispersion">variability</a> between disclosure practices based on industries and sizes. In 2008, the U.S Securities and Exchange Commission took a cautious approach in revising their public disclosure <a href="Earnings%20guidance">guidance</a> for social media companies and claim the information to be "<a href="Supplement%20%28publishing%29">supplemental</a> rather than <a href="Necessity%20and%20sufficiency">sufficient</a> by themselves". Alexander, Raquel, Gendry and James (2014) recommended that executives and managers should take a more <a href="Strategy">strategic</a> approach in managing <a href="investor%20relations">investor relations</a> and <a href="Corporate%20communication">corporate communications</a>, ensuring investor's and <a href="Financial%20analyst">analyst's</a> needs are jointly met.
Usage in academia.
Researching and web-behavioural analysis and prediction.
The active user metric can be particularly useful in <a href="User%20behavior%20analytics">behavioural analytics</a> and <a href="predictive%20analytics">predictive analytics</a>. The active user metric in the context of <a href="predictive%20analytics">predictive analytics</a> can be applied in a variety of fields including <a href="actuarial%20science">actuarial science</a>, <a href="marketing">marketing</a>, <a href="Financial%20services">finance services</a>, <a href="Health%20care">healthcare</a>, <a href="Online%20game">online-gaming</a>, and <a href="Social%20networking%20service">social networking</a>. Lewis, Wyatt, and Jeremy (2015), for example, have used this metric conducted a research in the fields of <a href="Health%20care">healthcare</a> to study quality and impacts of a mobile application and predicted usage limits of these applications.
Active users can also be used in studies that addresses the issue of <a href="mental%20health%20problems">mental health problems</a> that could cost the <a href="global%20economy">global economy</a> $16 Trillion U.S Dollars by 2030, if there is a lack of resource allocated for <a href="mental%20health">mental health</a>. Through web-behavioural analysis, Chuenphitthayavut, Zihuang, and Zhu (2020) discovered that the promotion of informational, social and <a href="Sympathy">emotional support</a> that represents media and public perception has positive effects on their research participants behavioural intention to use online mental health intervention. Online psychological educational program, a type of online mental health interventions are found to promote well-being, and decreased suicidal conception. 
In the fields of online-gaming, active users is quite useful in behaviour prediction and <a href="Churn%20rate">churn rates</a> of online games. For example, active user's features such "active Duration" and "play count" can have inverse <a href="Correlation%20and%20dependence">correlations</a> with churn rates, with "shorter play times and lower play count" associated with higher churn rates. Jia et Al. (2015) showed that there are social structures that transpire or emerge and centred around highly active players, with <a href="Structure">structural</a> similarity between <a href="Multiplayer%20video%20game">multiplayer online-games</a>, such as <a href="StarCraft%20II">StarCraft II</a> and <a href="Dota">Dota</a>.
The Active Users metric can be used to predict one's <a href="Trait%20theory">personality traits</a>, which can be classified and grouped into categories. These categories have accuracy that ranges from 84% - 92%. Based on the number of user's in a particular group, the internet object associated with it, can be deemed as "trending", and as an "area of interest". 
Ethical considerations and limitations.
With the internet's <a href="evolution">evolution</a> into a tool used for communications and <a href="Socialization">socialisation</a>, ethical considerations have also shifted from data-driven to "human-centered", further complicating the ethical issues relating with concepts of public and private on online domains, whereby researchers and subjects do not fully understand the <a href="Terms%20of%20service">terms and conditions</a> Ethical considerations need to be considered in terms of participative consent, <a href="Data%20security">data confidentiality-privacy-integrity</a>, and disciplinary-industry-professional <a href="Social%20norm">norms</a> and accepted <a href="Standard%20%28metrology%29">standards</a> in <a href="cloud%20computing">cloud computing</a> and <a href="big%20data">big data</a> research. Boehlefeld (1996) noted that researchers usually refer to ethical principals in their respective disciplines, as they seek guidance and recommended the guidelines by the <a href="Association%20for%20Computing%20Machinery">Association for Computing Machinery</a> to assist researchers of their responsibilities in their research studies in technological or <a href="cyberspace">cyberspace</a>.
<a href="Consent">Informed consent</a> refers to a situation that participant voluntarily participates in the research with full acknowledgement of the methods of research, risks and rewards associated. With the rise internet being used as a social networking tool, active users may face unique challenges in gaining informed consents. Ethical considerations may include <a href="The%20Degrees%20of%20Knowledge">degree of knowledge</a> to the participants and <a href="age%20appropriateness">age appropriateness</a>, ways and practicality in which researchers inform, and "when" it is appropriate to waive the consent. Crawford and Schultz (2014) have noted <a href="consent">consent</a> to be "innumerable" and "yet-to-be-determined" before the research is conducted. Grady et al. (2017) pointed out that <a href="Innovation">technological advancements</a> can assist in obtaining consent without the in-person meeting of investigators (researchers) and the <a href="Research%20participant">research participants</a>.
A large number of researches is based on individualised data, that encompass users <a href="online%20identity">online identity</a> (their clicks, readings, movements) and contents consumed and with data-analytics produced inferences about their <a href="Preference">preferences</a>, <a href="Social%20relation">social relationships</a>, and movement or work habits. In some cases, individuals may greatly benefit, but in others they can be harmed. Afolabi and García-Basteiro (2017) believed that informed consent to research studies is beyond "clicking blocks or supplying signature", as participants could have feel pressured in to joining the research, without researcher's awareness of the situation. There is yet to be a universally accepted form of <a href="Industry%20%28economics%29">industry</a> <a href="Standard%20%28metrology%29">standards</a> and <a href="Social%20norm">norms</a> in terms of data-privacy, <a href="confidentiality">confidentiality</a> and integrity, a critical ethics consideration, but there has been attempts to design a process to oversee the research activities and <a href="data%20collection">data collection</a> to better meet the <a href="community">community</a> and <a href="End%20user">end-user</a>'s expectations. There are also policy debates around ethical issues regarding the integration of <a href="Educational%20technology">edtech (education technology)</a> into <a href="K%E2%80%9312">K-12</a> education environment, as <a href="Minor%20%28law%29">minor</a> children are perceived to be most vulnerable segment of the entire population.
Technical limitations and challenges.
Many <a href="social%20media">social media</a> companies have their respective differences definition and <a href="calculation">calculation</a> methods of the active users metric. These differences often cause differences in the variable that the metric is measuring. Wyatt (2008) argues that there is evidence that some metrics reported by social media companies do not appear to be <a href="Reliability%20%28statistics%29">reliable</a>, as it requires categorical <a href="Judgement">judgements</a>, but is still value-relevant to <a href="financial%20statement">financial statement</a> users. Luft (2009) conveyed that non-financial metric, like active users, there presents challenges in measurement accuracy and appropriateness in weighting when coupled with <a href="accounting">accounting</a> reporting measures. There has been increasing notice from <a href="Business%20journalism">business presses</a> and academia. on <a href="Corporation%23Financial%2520disclosure">corporate</a> <a href="Convention%20of%20disclosure">conventions of disclosure</a> of these information. 
Active users are calculated using the internal data of the specific company. Data is collected based on unique users performing specific actions which data collectors deem as a sign of activity. These actions include visiting the home or <a href="Splash%20screen">splash page</a> of a website, logging in, commentating, uploading content, or similar actions which make use of the product. The number of people subscribed to a service may also be considered an active user for its duration. Each company has their own method of determining their number of active users, and many companies do not share specific details regarding how they calculate them. Some companies make changes to their calculation method over time. The specific action flagging users as active greatly impacts the quality of the data if it does not accurately reflect engagement with the product, resulting in misleading data. Basic actions such as logging into the product may not be an accurate representation of customer engagement and inflate the number of active users, while uploading content or commenting may be too specific for a product and under-represent user activity. 
Weitz, Henry and Rosenthal (2014) suggested that factors that may affect accuracy of metrics like active users include issues relating to definition and calculation, circumstances of <a href="Deception">deceptive</a> inflation, uncertainty <a href="Specification%20%28technical%20standard%29">specification</a> and user-shared, duplicate or fake accounts. The authors describes <a href="Facebook%2C%20Inc.">Facebook</a> monthly active users <a href="Criterion%20validity">criterion</a> as registered users past 30 days, have used the messenger, and took action to share <a href="Content%20%28media%29">content</a> and activity differing from <a href="LinkedIn">LinkedIn</a> who uses registered members, page visits and views. For example, a customer who uses the Facebook once, to "comment" or "share content", may also be counted as an "active user". A potential cause for these inaccuracies in measurement is the implemented <a href="Performance-related%20pay">Pay-for-Performance systems</a>, that encourages desired behaviours, included high-performance work system. In social media companies, active users is one of the crucial metric that measures the success of the product. Trueman, Wong, and Zhang (2000) have found that in most cases unique visitors and pageviews as a measurement of web-usage accounts for changes in stock prices, and net income in internet companies. Lazer, Lev and Livnat (2001) found that more popular website generated greater stock returns, in their research analysis of traffic data of internet companies through the division of higher and lower than median traffic data. Yielding <a href="Portfolio%20%28finance%29">portfolio</a> more returns may sway investors to vote on a more favourable bonus package for <a href="Executive%20director">executive management</a>. Kang, Lee and Na's (2010) research on the global financial crisis in 2007-2008 highlights the importance of prevention of "expropriation <a href="Incentive">incentives</a>" of investors, that provides very prominent implications on <a href="corporate%20governance">corporate governance</a>, especially during an <a href="Shock%20%28economics%29">economic shock.</a>
Active user is limited in examining pre-<a href="adoption">adoption</a> and post-adoption <a href="Behavior">behaviours</a> of users. Users commitment to a particular online <a href="Product%20%28business%29">product</a> may also depend on trust and the alternatives quality. Pre-<a href="adoption">adoption</a> behaviour's effects on post-adoption behaviour, that is predicted by past research has suggested, is found to have <a href="Correlation%20and%20dependence">associations</a> with factors such as habit, gender and some other <a href="Cultural%20psychology">socio-cultural</a> <a href="Demography">demographics</a>. Buchanan and Gillies (1990) and Reichheld and Schefter (2000) argues that post-adoption behaviours and continuous usage is "relatively more important than first-time or initial usage" as it shows "the degree of <a href="Brand%20loyalty">consumer loyalty</a>", and that ultimately produces long term <a href="Value%20product">product value</a>.
